thread.title: Ivanka Trump woos China with video of daughter singing in Chinese as suspicion lingers over president
thread.title_full: Ivanka Trump woos China with video of daughter singing in Chinese as suspicion lingers over president

author: Chris Graham
title: Ivanka Trump woos China with video of daughter singing in Chinese as suspicion lingers over president
text:
I t seemed to be Ivanka Trump's job during the presidential campaign to smooth things over when her father ruffled feathers with his frequent controversial remarks.
Now, she may be attempting to replicate the dynamic on the world stage.
Donald Trump, who had already caused anger by taking a call from Taiwan's leader shortly after winning the election, irked the Chinese further by failing to send greetings for the Lunar New Year last weekend.
His daughter and granddaughter, meanwhile, are currently the darlings of the Chinese internet after Ivanka visited the Chinese embassy and posted a clip on Twitter of her daughter singing in Chinese.
Arabella singing a song she learned for #ChineseNewYear . Wishing everyone an amazing year to come during these days of celebration. 新年快乐！ pic.twitter.com/jxHHLvhmzm 
— Ivanka Trump (@IvankaTrump) February 2, 2017 T he brief video shows five-year-old Arabella Kushner singing best wishes for the holiday while playing with a traditional Chinese puppet.
The pair made a surprise visit to the Chinese Embassy in Washington on Wednesday to take part in the Lunar New Year festivities, a photo of which was splashed across the front page of the official China Daily newspaper on Friday.
Arabella had already become a hit with the Chinese when a video clip of her reciting an ancient Chinese poem went viral in November.
State news agency Xinhua, meanwhile, asked Twitter users if they thought Ivanka looked like Chinese actress Li Bingbing, adding a video comparing the two women. The overwhelming response was "no". 
Similar faces: Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka and Chinese actress Li Bingbing. Do you think they look like each other? pic.twitter.com/s68ZNC2Lsf 
— China Xinhua News (@XHNews) February 3, 2017 W hile the Trump women received plaudits, the lack of a greeting from the president "triggered heated discussion" among the Chinese public over the possible ramifications for bilateral relations, the official newspaper Global Times said on Friday.
The paper noted that Mr Trump's most recent predecessors Bill Clinton, George W. Bush and Barack Obama "all delivered Lunar New Year greetings to Asians who celebrate this festival.
"Some Chinese (internet) users felt Trump was being disrespectful by not sending a greeting," the paper said.
The Lunar New Year , which this year fell on last Saturday, is China's most important traditional holiday, a time for family gatherings, feasts and the exchange of greetings between relatives, friends and work colleagues. It is also celebrated in several other Asian countries and among Chinese communities worldwide.
Comments on the internet largely focused on what many Chinese view as a hawkish attitude by Mr Trump and his administration toward China, with many saying the lack of a greeting should be seen as a deliberate snub.
Interesting how the U.S. sells Taiwan billions of dollars of military equipment but I should not accept a congratulatory call.
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) December 3, 2016 M r Trump caused a diplomatic row when he took a call from Taiwan's president shortly after winning the election in November, a move that raised doubts about his commitment to the decades old "One China" policy". 
Did China ask us if it was OK to devalue their currency (making it hard for our companies to compete), heavily tax our products going into..
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) December 4, 2016 H e then accused Beijing of manipulating the value of its currency to gain an advantage in trade and threatened to impose a 45 percent tariff on imports from China.
their country (the U.S. doesn't tax them) or to build a massive military complex in the middle of the South China Sea? I don't think so!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) December 4, 2016 H e's also criticised China's military buildup in the South China Sea and accused Beijing of doing too little to pressure neighbour North Korea over its nuclear and missile programmes. 
His use of Twitter to weigh in on foreign policy has also not gone down well in China, with Xinhua publishing a commentary headlined: "An obsession with 'Twitter foreign policy' is undesireable".
Twitter diplomacy | Trumps foreign policy tweets
